sections.label: What do you hope to learn?
options: How the Old Testament points to Jesus
What the Law and Prophets are about

responses.How the Old Testament points to Jesus: That’s huge! You’ll begin to see how the entire Old Testament sets the stage for Jesus — He’s woven into every part of the story.
responses.What the Law and Prophets are about: Great choice! You’ll uncover how the Law shaped God's people and how the Prophets called them (and us) back to His heart.
responses.God’s covenant and promises: So important — the covenants show God’s commitment to rescue and bless, which continues through Jesus.
responses.Major figures and events: You’re in for some powerful stories! You’ll meet leaders, prophets, and ordinary people that God used in extraordinary ways.

enhanced.title: The Big Picture
enhanced.description: The Old Testament spans from Creation to centuries before Jesus’ birth, laying the foundation of God’s plan of redemption.

enhanced.title: Core Themes Covered
enhanced.description: We'll explore major themes such as the Law, Covenant, Worship, Kingship, Prophets, Exile, and the anticipation of the Messiah.

enhanced.title: Key Figures
enhanced.description: You'll meet people like Abraham, Moses, David, and the Prophets—each playing a vital role in God's unfolding plan.

enhanced.title: How It Connects to Jesus
enhanced.description: The Old Testament constantly points forward to Jesus—the ultimate fulfillment of the promises, sacrifices, and prophecies.

enhanced.title: What You'll Learn
enhanced.description: Each unit will walk through the Law & Foundation, Key People, Kingdoms, Prophets, and how it all leads to the New Covenant.

enhanced.title: Creation & Covenant
enhanced.description: God creates the world, makes a covenant with Abraham (Genesis 12), and forms a holy people through the Exodus.

enhanced.title: The Law Given
enhanced.description: Through Moses, God gives His Law (Exodus 20, Leviticus) to shape Israel's moral and spiritual life. Jesus would fulfill this Law (Matthew 5:17).

enhanced.title: Moses, the Deliverer
enhanced.description: A type of Christ, Moses delivers Israel from slavery and mediates a covenant, much like Jesus delivers us from sin and mediates a new covenant (Hebrews 9:15).

enhanced.title: Sacrifices & Worship
enhanced.description: The sacrificial system in Leviticus pointed to the seriousness of sin and the need for a perfect sacrifice—fulfilled in Jesus.

enhanced.title: Priesthood
enhanced.description: God established the priesthood through Aaron to intercede for the people, symbolizing Jesus as our ultimate High Priest.

enhanced.title: Abraham: Father of Nations
enhanced.description: God promised Abraham his descendants would bless the whole world (Genesis 12). Jesus is the fulfillment of that promise (Galatians 3:29).

enhanced.title: Isaac & Jacob
enhanced.description: The covenant passed through Isaac and Jacob, showing how God's promise continues despite flaws and failures.

subUnits.title: Key Figures of the Old Testament

enhanced.title: Abraham
enhanced.description: The father of faith, Abraham trusted God’s promises and became the root of God’s covenant people – Genesis 12, 15.

enhanced.title: Moses
enhanced.description: Led the Israelites out of Egypt and received the Law at Mount Sinai. His life points to Jesus as the ultimate deliverer.

enhanced.title: David
enhanced.description: A shepherd-king who wrote many Psalms. God's covenant with David (2 Samuel 7) points to Jesus, the eternal King.

enhanced.title: Joseph
enhanced.description: Betrayed and imprisoned, yet used by God to save nations—foreshadowing Jesus' suffering and exaltation.

sections.label: Quick Quiz
sections.question: Who received God's covenant promise that his descendants would bless the world?

sections.label: Think About This
sections.question: Which Old Testament figure do you most relate to, and why?

scripture.text: Now faith is confidence in what we hope for and assurance about what we do not see.

sections.prompt: The people in the Old Testament were flawed but faithful. Their stories show us how to walk with God through doubt, trials, and growth.
sections.inputPlaceholder: How do their stories encourage or challenge your faith?

enhanced.title: The Fall of the Kingdom
enhanced.description: Because of unfaithfulness, Israel and Judah were conquered and taken into exile (2 Kings 17, 25).

enhanced.title: Hope in the Darkness
enhanced.description: Even in exile, prophets like Jeremiah and Ezekiel spoke of God’s promises and a future hope (Jeremiah 29:11).

enhanced.title: The Return and Rebuilding
enhanced.description: Led by Ezra and Nehemiah, the people returned and rebuilt Jerusalem. But they still waited for a true Savior.

enhanced.title: Looking Ahead to Jesus
enhanced.description: The Old Testament closes with anticipation. Jesus would come as the true King, Temple, and Redeemer.

sections.label: Quick Quiz
sections.question: Who led the effort to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem after the exile?

sections.label: Think About This
sections.question: How does God's faithfulness during exile give you hope today?

scripture.text: Because of the Lord’s great love we are not consumed... his mercies are new every morning.

sections.prompt: God didn’t abandon His people, even when they strayed. He still brings us home.
sections.inputPlaceholder: Where have you seen God's mercy in hard times?

enhanced.title: Joseph – From Pit to Purpose
enhanced.description: Sold by his brothers and wrongly imprisoned, Joseph remained faithful. God used him to save many lives—foreshadowing Jesus (Genesis 50:20).

enhanced.title: Ruth – Loyal and Redeemed
enhanced.description: Ruth, a Moabite widow, chose faith and loyalty. Her story of redemption leads directly to the family line of Jesus (Ruth 4:17).

enhanced.title: Esther – Bold in the Face of Fear
enhanced.description: Esther risked her life to save her people. Her courage reminds us that God places us in specific moments 'for such a time as this' (Esther 4:14).

sections.label: Quick Quiz
sections.question: Which woman became the great-grandmother of King David?

sections.label: Think About This
sections.question: How can ordinary faith lead to extraordinary impact?

scripture.text: God chose the weak things of the world to shame the strong.

sections.prompt: None of these people started in powerful positions—but God used them in mighty ways.
sections.inputPlaceholder: What simple act of faith could God use in your life?

enhanced.title: Major Prophets
enhanced.description: Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, and Daniel brought major messages of judgment, hope, and restoration.

enhanced.title: Minor Prophets
enhanced.description: 12 shorter books from Hosea to Malachi address both personal and national sins, and point to God’s mercy.

enhanced.title: Pointing to Jesus
enhanced.description: Many prophets foretold the coming of the Messiah. Isaiah 53 speaks of a suffering servant—fulfilled in Jesus.

sections.label: Quick Quiz
sections.question: Which prophet spoke about a 'suffering servant' who would bear our sins?

sections.label: Think About This
sections.question: What can we learn from how the prophets called people to return to God?

scripture.text: He was pierced for our transgressions... by His wounds we are healed.

sections.prompt: The prophets didn’t just warn—they offered hope. God still calls people back today.
sections.inputPlaceholder: What message from the prophets stands out most to you?

enhanced.title: God’s Story from the Start
enhanced.description: The Old Testament is the foundation of God’s plan to rescue and redeem. It reveals His heart, His covenant, and His promise to send a Savior.

enhanced.title: Jesus: The Fulfillment
enhanced.description: Every law, leader, prophet, and promise points toward Jesus—the ultimate Redeemer who brings the New Covenant.

enhanced.title: Your Place in the Story
enhanced.description: God’s story is not over. You are invited to walk in faith, just like those before you, and live in light of His promises.
